titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Parker Family Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Susan Grigg

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 09:49

did.unittitle: Parker Family Papers

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The collection consists of correspondence, poems, estate papers, notebooks, account books, logbooks, legal books, and miscellaneous papers of the Lay, Parker, Pratt, Shaler, Smith, Stark, Tyler, and Williams families of eastern Connecticut.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Parker Family Papers (MS 685). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Whitlock's in 1941-1944; in part by gift of Carroll A. Means in 1941.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Parker Family Papers consist of letters, legal and financial records, and miscellaneous items of the Parker, Lay, and other families with roots in eastern coastal Connecticut in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. The Parker family represented here is that of Gideon Parker of Essex and his children, principally his sons John L. and Gideon M., who were engaged in trade in Essex and in Key West, Florida, and Mobile, Alabama. The Parker papers are mainly commercial records and family correspondence. The Lay family papers consist of deeds and miscellaneous items belonging to members of several generations of the Lay and allied families of Saybrook, Westbrook, and Guilford, Connecticut. The Stark family is represented by correspondence of two households: Benjamin Stark of New London, San Francisco, and Portland, Oregon; and Jonathan Stark and his children of Portersville in Groton. There are also commercial papers of Nathan Tyler, B[enoni?] Southworth, and two men named Timothy Shaler; several manuscript poems, including a striking denunciation of "British Taxation in North America" signed by Lucy D. Geer of Groton; and letters by William S. Williams of Michigan and Mary Avery Smith (later Mrs. Rowland Sears) of Petersburg and Albany, New York, to their relatives in Connecticut and New York.

The Parker Family Papers were purchased from Whitlock's in several lots between 1941 and 1944, except that the photostats of the Benjamin Stark letters were made by courtesy of Carroll A. Means at the time of sale of the original letters at the Collector's Shop in 1941.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

did.unittitle: Inventory
Lay family
DeWolf, Lucy Rebecca (Lay) Rawson, of Westbrook, Conn., and Green River, Vt.
2 ALS to her son, Edward Lay Rawson
2 ALS to her sister, Emmie Elizabeth Lay
Dupee, James A., of Boston: ALS to Annie L. Prince
Hayden, Jerusha, of the Wallingford Union Academy: poem, "On the death of Alfred Lay"
Holcomb, Medad (d. 1858) of Guilford: estate papers
Kimball, W.A. with the U.S. Army in Centreville, Va.; 2 ALS to his family (copies)
Lay, Alfred French (1794-1810): two school notebooks
Lay, Asa (1749-1814) of Saybrook: estate papers
Lay, Asa (1749-1814): Captain Asa Lay of the War for Independence , by Mary Hewitt Mitchell
Lay, Edward Bliss (1792-[1864-1865]) of Westbrook: will (copy)
Lay, Emmie Elizabeth (1828-1903)
ALS to her brother-in-law and sister, John S. Starr and Lydia Austin (Lay) Starr
AL (incomplete) from an unidentified correspondent of Westbrook
Lay, Jonathan W. (1825-1893) of Georgia, Vt.: ALS to his brother-in-law and sister, John S. Starr and Lydia Austin (Lay) Starr of Guilford, Conn.
Lay, Lucy White (1797-1884):
Commonplace book (Saybrook)
Will (Westbrook; copy)
Lay, Martha (Wright) (Mrs. Steuben) of Norwich Conn.: ALS to her brother, David Wright of Boston
Lay, Richard W., of Guilford: ALS to his uncle
Lay, Robert, of Saybrook: agreement between his son and executor, Samuel Lay, and his son-in-law and daughter, Jabez and Dorotha (Lay) Denison, all of Saybrook
Lay, Samuel, of Saybrook: account book, later used as a scrapbook for clippings
Lay, Sarah (Wolcott) (1752-1840) of Saybrook: estate papers
Lay, Steuben (1787-1869) of Westbrook: estate papers
Leete, Charles Frederic (1820-)
Insurance policies
List of Leete and Hubbard deaths
Invitation to a reception given by Orville H. Platt
"List of Charles F. Leets house"
Rawson, Edward Lay (1858-): 4 ALS to members of his family
Rawson, Grindal (1803-1869): ALS to his son (Edward D. Rawson?) and daughter
Stone, Joseph F., of New York: ALS to his uncle, Abram S. Fowler of Guilford, Conn.
Wright, Charles Townsend, visiting at Marion Courthouse, S.C.: power of attorney to Mary H. Wright of Norwich, Conn.
Guilford deeds
Saybrook deeds
Westbrook deeds
Parker family
Parker, Gideon Marsena
Account books
Letter press book
Parker, John L.
Log book for the ships Edwina and Severn
Memorandum books
Account book
Parker, Rebecca E. (Shaler or Lay?) (Mrs. John): account book with entries covered by a newspaper account of the American Congress of Churches
Correspondence and miscellaneous papers
Pratt family
Latimer, Arvilla (Pratt): recipe book
Pratt, Sarah E., of Essex, Conn.: composition book
Shaler, Timothy, of (East) Haddam, Conn.
Safe-conduct pass for the schooner George
Letter
Account book
Legal papers
Smith family
Sears, Mary Avery (Smith) (Mrs. Rowland Sears, 1794-1878) of Petersburg and Albany, N.Y.: letters to her sister, Clarinda (Smith) Frink (Mrs. Adam Frink, 1786-1858) of Russia, N.Y.
Southworth, B[enoni, Jr.?], of (East) Haddam, Conn.
Accounts with members of the Shaler family for the sloop and schooner America
Letter
Stark, Benjamin (1820-1898) of San Francisco and Portland, Ore.: incoming business letters; letters to his mother, Mrs. Benjamin Stark, and brother, William W. Stark of New London, Conn. (photostats)
Stark family of Portersville, Groton, Conn.

Letters to Jonathan Stark from his brother-in-law, William A. Reed, and nephew, Isaac C. Reed of Goshen, Conn., and Ill., and his brother Lathrop of Bozrah, Conn.; letters to and from Jonathan Stark's sons, Russell, sailing out of Savannah, and William, sailing in the brig Emeline
Tyler, Frances R., of Boston and Essex, Conn.: diary and account book
Tyler, William S.: account book
Tyler, Nathan
Bound volume containing a log of the sloop Lark , miscellaneous maritime notations, and a poem, "The Old Maid's Petition"
Papers re: British compensation for the confiscation of the sloop Lark
Williams, William S. (d. 1834) and Emily W. (Mrs. W.S.) of Detroit and Pontiac, Michigan: letters to his brother, Joseph S. Williams, and his mother, Thankful Williams, of Mystic Bridge, Conn.
Poems
Geer, Lucy D., of Groton, Conn.: "British Taxation in North America" (manuscript)
"James Bird," re: the Kingston Volunteers in the Lake Erie campaign (manuscript)
"Sword Presentation, at Middletown, Oct. 7th, 1862" (printed)
"Poetry Poetry: Fire in New York; Fishermans Girl; Crazy Jane" (manuscript)
"Cold Water Army Pledge" (printed)
New Haven (city): At a City Meeting Holden in New-Haven, April 22, 1806. A Bye-Law for establishing and regulating a Market...
Miscellaneous papers
